item.title: Banks make $38bn from overdraft fees
item.description: US banks stand to collect a record $38.5bn in fees for customer overdrafts this year, with the bulk of the revenue coming from the most financially stretched consumers amid the deepest recession since the 1930s, according to research

item.title: Wall Street set to open lower
item.description: US stocks looked set to drift from last week’s highs with investors looking to bank profits even as several closely watched experts gave a relatively bullish analysis for the equity markets

item.title: Crisis and climate force supply chain shift
item.description: Manufacturers are abandoning global supply chains for regional ones in a big shift brought about by the financial crisis and climate change concerns, according to executives and analysts

item.title: Bombs in Baghdad and northern Iraq kill 41
item.description: Bombs in Shia Muslim areas in Baghdad and northern Iraq killed 41 people, police said, the latest of several major attacks since US combat troops withdrew from urban centres in June

item.title: China says Rio spying has cost it $100bn
item.description: Beijing has accused mining group Anglo-Australian miner Rio Tinto of spying on its steel industry for six years, a move that indicates the detention of four Rio employees on accusations of stealing state secrets could be the start of a widening campaign rather than an isolated case

item.title: UK highlights threat to food security
item.description: Genetically modified crops could form be part of the solution for making British agriculture more self-sufficient, environment minister Hilary Benn conceded as the government launched its first review of Britain’s food security

item.title: Facebook joins forces with advertisers
item.description: More than 80 per cent of the largest US advertisers are using Facebook to promote themselves, suggesting that corporate America has embraced the social networking site as a mainstream promotional platform

item.title: Fraud spotlight on Hollywood
item.description: A Los Angeles trial involving incidents in Thailand could have repercussions across the entertainment sector

item.title: UK security man held over killings in Iraq
item.description: A British private security contractor was taken into custodyarrested by Iraqi authorities in Baghdad’s protected Green Zone, accused of fatally shooting two colleagues, a Briton and an Australian

item.title: Aluminium riding high on futures dealing
item.description: Aluminium prices at the London Metal Exchange have surged beyond the $2,000 a tonne mark, a gravity-defying recovery in the face of falling demand and a growing supply surplus
